div.p: The vicessitudes of Life are many, & those come upon Mankind unexpectedly, which require the exercise of Christian fortitude in the strongest degree: — I am sorry to learn that you have lost so many Friends, heartily do I wish this may be supplied by the comfortable enjoyment of your Family, especialy when engaged so laudably in the acquisition of Knowledge: may your Son's Visit abroad be prosperous & his Return to Britain again be safe. — From a Paper lately fallen into my hands, written by my Father I cannot look for the length of my days now, as it assures me to have past more years than I thought i.e since July 1721, but to drop this topick at the time, — let us pass our Lives as we ought to do.

I am glad that the short hints on the Salt were of any Service to you, return thanks for the Specimen of your Labour, with what you may be pleased to oblige the World with I shall be always happy to peruse & assign a carefull corner in my small Collection.

Mr. Smellie's Philosophy of Natural History
was published t'other day, an Acquaintance passing to London now on the way I am hopefull that you will find two Copies, shortly hence, at Mr. White's Bookseller for your Acceptance from me, having ordered the Parcel to be left there to meet you while residing in London expecting this will reach you in due time.

You have inclosed Kay's Sketch of Capt. Grose, hope he will soon begin his Tour in our Western Regions,The antiquarian Francis Grose made tours of Scotland in 1788, 1789 and 1790, in order to gather materials for his
Antiquities of Scotland
, published 1789-1791. if you chance to see him, my best Compliments wait of him, I do hear that the
old Tower house of Udny in Aberdeenshire is well worthy of his inspection, the plan of this building being of a singular kind: a draft of it was made by Doctor Anderson, if he has a Copy thereof, I shall solicit a Sketch of it for you from him. — The Doctor some days ago exprest his warmest returns for the Civilities you shewed him while you was in the north of this Country, his Letter to me with his M.S Plan I inclose for your perusal & if your Son can procure the Literary Countenance of any qualified Person in the Course of his Travels, this would be a very high piece of merit to Dr. Anderson to gain their Correspondence, such a plan as he pourposes will be of real Service to the world: — when his proposals are printed I shall be sure to lend you some of them, the inclosed is handed for your recomendation of its contents for your's notice if deserving it.The proposal and manuscript plan Paton refers to likey relate to James Anderson's attempts to gather support for his periodical project,
The Bee, or Literary Weekly Intelligencer
(1791-1794), a
Prospectus
for which was printed in 1790.

Mr. Cardonnel desired me to present his best Compliments with gratefull thanks for the Drafts he received from you by Capt. Grose. — I've added a portrait of a remarkable Man at Dunfermline, he is an adept in the Hebrew &c. & other Eastern Languages from some peculiarity has refrained the shaving or cutting his Beards, have seen him walking thro' our Streets, but the young Boys now restrain their following after him as an uncommon person; he was educated to have been a Clergyman: Dr. Lort when here was much pleased that Portrait, it is very like him.Several portraits of Lort are known to have been made. Paton may be referring to John Downman's 1777 portrait, or Francis Grose's more recent caricature of Lort, The Antiquarian Mastiff .

closer.salute:
I am sincerely
Dr. Sir
Your most obedt. Servt.
